title: Mendelian randomization Methods Network
text:
Welcome to the Mendelian randomization Methods Network (MRMN)






Mission statement



A network of Mendelian randomization analysts and methods developers who aim to build an annotated methods repository





Directed acyclic graph representing the three instrumental variable core conditions underlying the Mendelian randomization approach.














LHC-MR



GWAS summary statistics for both exposure(s) and outcome(s) (or all traits if Network MR),Univariable MR (one exposure, one outcome),Effect direction orientation,Bi-directional relationships,Estimation

title: LHC-MR
text: We propose a Latent Heritable Confounder MR (LHC-MR) method applicable to association summary statistics, which estimates bi-directional causal effects, direct heritability, and confounder effects while accounting for sample overlap.

title: LHC-MR
text: We propose a Latent Heritable Confounder MR (LHC-MR) method applicable to association summary statistics, which estimates bi-directional causal effects, direct heritability, and confounder effects while accounting for sample overlap.

title: CAUSE
text: A Bayesian MR method accounting for correlated and uncorrelated horizontal pleiotropy.

title: Background

title: R-Universe
text:
The MRC IEU R-universe https://mrcieu.r-universe.dev distributes binary R packages for many MR related packages which are currently only available on GitHub and have to be installed from source. Especially on Linux, installing packages from source can be very slow. The binary packages are available for several operating systems; Windows, macOS with Intel processors, and Ubuntu Linux 22.04 Jammy Jellyfish (and more will be available as the R-universe system extends).
If you would like a package added to the universe please open an issue in our repository.
Additionally, each package included in the R-Universe has its own webpages, meaning you can read the rendered vignettes, which is helpful if a package does not have its own website, e.g.,

the R-Universe webpage for TwoSampleMR
and its exposure data vignette

title: R-Universe
text:
The MRC IEU R-universe https://mrcieu.r-universe.dev distributes binary R packages for many MR related packages which are currently only available on GitHub and have to be installed from source. Especially on Linux, installing packages from source can be very slow. The binary packages are available for several operating systems; Windows, macOS with Intel processors, and Ubuntu Linux 22.04 Jammy Jellyfish (and more will be available as the R-universe system extends).
If you would like a package added to the universe please open an issue in our repository.
Additionally, each package included in the R-Universe has its own webpages, meaning you can read the rendered vignettes, which is helpful if a package does not have its own website, e.g.,

title: R-Universe
section: How to install binary R packages from the MRC IEU R-universe
text:
How to install binary R packages from the MRC IEU R-universe
To install binary R packages from the MRC IEU R-universe, include the URL in your repos list as shown below.

Windows and Intel Mac users
For Windows and Intel Mac users to install the binary version of TwoSampleMR, run the following code.
# Installation code for Windows and Intel Mac users
install.packages(
  'TwoSampleMR',
  repos = c(
    'https://mrcieu.r-universe.dev',
    'https://cloud.r-project.org'
  )
)


Ubuntu Linux users
For Ubuntu Linux Jammy Jellyfish users running R through RStudio Desktop or RStudio Server, to install TwoSampleMR run the following code.
# Installation code for Ubuntu Jammy Jellyfish users in RStudio Desktop or Server
install.packages(
  'TwoSampleMR',
  repos = c(
    'https://mrcieu.r-universe.dev/bin/linux/jammy/4.3/',
    'https://packagemanager.posit.co/cran/__linux__/jammy/latest',
    'https://cloud.r-project.org'
  )
)
For Ubuntu Linux Jammy Jellyfish users running R in the Terminal first amend the HTTPUserAgent option,1 and then run the Linux installation code above. If the HTTPUserAgent option is not amended it seems that source rather than binary packages are obtained for the Imports dependency packages from the Posit Public Package Manager’s CRAN packages. For this case, to install TwoSampleMR, run the following code.
# Installation code for Ubuntu Jammy Jellyfish users running R in the Terminal
options(HTTPUserAgent = sprintf(
  "R/%s R (%s)",
  getRversion(),
  paste(getRversion(),
        R.version["platform"],
        R.version["arch"],
        R.version["os"])
))

install.packages(
  'TwoSampleMR',
  repos = c(
    'https://mrcieu.r-universe.dev/bin/linux/jammy/4.3/',
    'https://packagemanager.posit.co/cran/__linux__/jammy/latest',
    'https://cloud.r-project.org'
  )
)

title: MRBEE
text: We introduce MRBEE (MR using Bias-corrected Estimating Equation), a novel multivariable MR method capable of simultaneously removing error-in-variable bias and identi16 fying horizontal pleiotropy.

title: MRBEE
text: We introduce MRBEE (MR using Bias-corrected Estimating Equation), a novel multivariable MR method capable of simultaneously removing error-in-variable bias and identi16 fying horizontal pleiotropy.

title: Weak instrument robust MVMR
text: A method for multivariable mendelian randomization to test for weak instruments and estimate causal effects that are robust to weak instruments.

title: Weak instrument robust MVMR
text: A method for multivariable mendelian randomization to test for weak instruments and estimate causal effects that are robust to weak instruments.

title: MR-RAPS
text: MR-RAPS is an MR method using a consistent asymptotically normal estimator that improves weak instrument bias and accounts for horizontal pleiotropy using a random effect and an outlier robust loss function

title: MR-RAPS
text: MR-RAPS is an MR method using a consistent asymptotically normal estimator that improves weak instrument bias and accounts for horizontal pleiotropy using a random effect and an outlier robust loss function

title: Submission
text:
Methods can be included here in two ways
Ideally you would submit the method to the software registry first, and then link to the software in the meta data submission.
